notes:
1. Definition

A buffer solution (or simply, a buffer) is an aqueous solution consisting of a mixture of a weak acid and its conjugate base, or a weak base and its conjugate acid. Buffers have the property that their pH changes very little when a small amount of strong acid or strong base is added to them.

2. How Buffers Work

A buffer works by neutralizing added acid or base. Consider a buffer made of a weak acid ($HA$) and its conjugate base ($A^-$).

  • When a strong acid ($H^+$) is added, the conjugate base reacts with it: $A^- + H^+ \rightarrow HA$.
  • When a strong base ($OH^-$) is added, the weak acid reacts with it: $HA + OH^- \rightarrow A^- + H_2O$.

In both cases, the strong acid or base is converted into a weak acid or base, which causes a much smaller change in pH than the strong acid/base would have caused on its own.

3. Henderson-Hasselbalch Equation

This equation relates the pH of a buffer solution to the acid dissociation constant ($K_a$) of the weak acid and the ratio of the concentrations of the conjugate base to the weak acid.

$$ pH = pK_a + \log_{10}\left(\frac{[A^-]}{[HA]}\right) $$

where $pK_a = -\log_{10}(K_a)$. This equation shows that the pH of a buffer is most effective (changes the least) when the concentrations of the acid and its conjugate base are equal ($[A^-]/[HA] = 1$). At this point, $pH = pK_a$.

solvedExamples.question: Which of the following pairs would make an effective buffer solution?

options.text: HC₂H₃O₂ (acetic acid, a weak acid) and NaC₂H₃O₂ (its conjugate base)

solvedExamples.explanation: A buffer solution consists of a weak acid and its conjugate base, or a weak base and its conjugate acid. Acetic acid is a weak acid, and sodium acetate provides its conjugate base (the acetate ion), so this pair will form a buffer.

solvedExamples.question: A buffer is most effective at resisting pH change when:

options.text: The concentration of the weak acid is much greater than the conjugate base.
The concentration of the conjugate base is much greater than the weak acid.
The concentrations of the weak acid and its conjugate base are approximately equal.

solvedExamples.explanation: According to the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation, when $[A^-] = [HA]$, the ratio is 1, and $\log(1) = 0$. This means $pH = pK_a$. At this point, the buffer has equal capacity to neutralize both added acid and added base, making it most effective.
